descriptionMarkdown:
# Simple usage example of a counter.

Assume that the value of "C" in the second arithmetic combinator is set to 0 by default. I abbreviate "copper plate" as "copper"

1. the incoming items on the belt (copper) are read. For each incoming copper, a pulse with the value  "1 copper" is sent to the arithmetic combinator  
2. this value is multiplied by 2 to get a value of "2 copper" for each copper   
3. In the next arithmetic combinator, the value of "C" is increased by the value of the copper signal, "-2"  
so we get  C  = C - 2 for each copper entering the belt
4. The copper passes through the machine (at a really bad ratio), gets used up and converted into 2 copper wires for each copper plate.   
5. In the next belt-scanner, the copper wire value "1 copper wire" is multiplied by -1 to get "-1 copper wire" for each copper wire. We output this new value under the label "C" to get "-1 C". This signal gets combined into the input to the 2nd arithmetic combinator to lower the value of C by 1 for each copper wire.    
6.  The inserter adds copper to the belt (stacksize overridden to 1), and stops when the value of "C" reaches 10.  

The goal is to pass 1 copper plate into the system for every 2 copper wires coming out, with a maximum total of 5 copper plates in the system.
title: Counter Example : limiting input based on output
